Consequently, many are reluctant to leave their homes and friends or partners for other locations. Training more doctors in Sydney will result in more doctors staying in Sydney. In many regions in Sydney, bulk-billing rates are very high as competition is high because, it seems, we have doctors on just about every corner. AgainI suggest that it would make far more sense to increase student numbers in non-metropolitan medical schools such as Newcastle, with its well-placed satellite facilities on the Central Coast and in Tamworth, and only then consider new medical schools, which should be established in non-metropolitan areas. Finally, a new medical school requires access to clinical facilities and to patients. Establishing two new medical schools in Sydney will put a demand on existing clinical facilities and MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon (Hunter) (11.06 A.m.)
theText: There is no more important issue in my elecpatient numbers that probably cannot be met. The medical schools of the universities of Sydney and New South Wales already have difficulty in providing adequate clinical placements for their own students. So there are many issues surrounding doctor numbers in this country. But in the medium to long term there can be no doubt that the best way to get doctors into rural and regional areas is to get more young people from the bush interested in medicine and training to practice in medicine. Again, the best way to do that is to give them the opportunity to train in regional areas, and there is no greater opportunity than the school provided by the University of Newcastle. In Maitland, another major town in my electorate, thanks to a very good initiative of a number of community members, particularly the Hunter Division of Urban Practice, for some years we have had a GP after-hours service operating at Maitland Hospital. It has been enormously successful in providing after-hours medical services to local residents. It has been so successful that it has become a national model for after-hours GP services. I am delighted that the Labor Party has picked up that model and run with it and has made a huge commitment to growing those services around the nation in areas of need. I was delighted earlier this week when the member for Paterson announced an additional amount of money to keep that Maitland service going. I must say that it is amazing what an election campaign can do, because only a short time ago Mr Baldwin, the member for Paterson, was arguing that no such commitment was necessary. I am a bit suspicious about the timing, but we welcome the funding. Dickson Electorate: Health Services portant issue to Pine Rivers and to the people of my electorate in relation to the state of health services in the Pine Rivers Shire. I have spoken on a number of occasions before in the parliament in relation to the desperation that some people in the electorate of Dickson are feeling in relation to the inadequate provision of health services. It is why I have spent the last three years fighting for additional doctors to come to the Pine Rivers area for additional services to be provided to young families and to older residents who are calling Pine Rivers their home not just for now but for many years to come. I have reported to the House before that we have been the most successful area in attracting doctors under the outer metropolitan areas scheme. We have had 18 doctors attracted to the Pine Rivers Shire. That is the highest number in the country, and it is a fact of which we are very proud because it is something that we fought very hard for over the last three years. The important point to note is that there is still more to be done. We still need more doctors in Pine Rivers. We still need to have more medical services in Pine Rivers. That is the reason why today I renew my call to the state government in Queensland to look at the prospect of establishing a hospital in Pine Rivers-one of the fastest growing regions in this country. It is a commitment that the Queensland government needs to decide upon and to make for the people of Pine Rivers. The state government puts forward the argument that there are adequate services being provided at Redcliffe and at Caboolture, that there are outpatient services at the Royal Brisbane Hospital and that medical services are being provided at the Prince Charles Hospital, which is also on the north side of Brisbane. But there is a glaring deficiency in the services that are provided to the people of Pine Rivers. Last night I spoke with a lady who is 72 years of age who detailed to me her horrific interaction with the hospital services in Queensland. That has only made my calls for a public hosMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Dutton (Dickson) (11.11 A.m.)
theText: It is my pleasure to speak again about the very impital in Pine Rivers all the more necessary. I have heard some horror stories from people in my area about the way in which they have been treated when attending state public hospitals on the north side of Brisbane. But the details that were provided to me last night by this 72year-old lady, who lives at Bray Park in my electorate, really made me feel quite disgusted at the inadequacy of the services provided, in this case, at the Royal Brisbane Hospital. This lady told me that she was taken by ambulance on Monday morning of this week, after having been advised by her local doctor that she needed to attend hospital. She had a drip put in her arm and she was taken by ambulance to the Royal Brisbane Hospital. She arrived at the Royal Brisbane Hospital on Monday at 1 p.m. and she was discharged at midday on the Tuesday. She had spent the time from 1 p.m. on the Monday afternoon in the accident and emergency section of the Royal Brisbane Hospital in a cubicle. A lady 72 years of age had spent almost 24 hours in the accident and emergency section of the Royal Brisbane Hospital without any referral to a ward and without being admitted into the hospital. She did nothing but sing the praises of the staff and the doctors that are there, but she told the story that the doctors are simply overburdened. The doctors and the nurses told her that there are no beds available and there are certainly no staff to provide the services in the beds that are there, so this 72-year-old lady spent her time in the accident and emergency section in a cubicle overnight. She was not able to get to sleep; and at seven o’clock the next morning she was shipped out of the cubicle into a lounge chair because the ambulances started a fresh round of bringing people into the accident and emergency section. And the story she told was not unfamiliar, because it is a tragic circumstance which is being played out in hospitals right across the north side of Brisbane and, indeed, right through Queensland. TodayI renew my call to the state government-one of desperation-to look at the provision of a hospital in Pine Rivers. I have said before in this parliament that I have spoken with the shire council in Pine Rivers. They are in a position to provide land. We now need the state government to respond to the letters that I sent on 7 August 2003, 7 October 2003 and 8 December 2003 and a number of calls that I have provided to the health minister’s office in Queensland. There has not been one response to the people of Pine Rivers, and it is a disgrace. Health: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Machines General Hospital and the 130,000 constituents I represent in my electorate of Lowe. This week I tabled yet another petition-the 11th petition-with now more than 10,000 signatures calling on the Minister for Health and Ageing, the Hon. Tony Abbott, to grant Concord hospital a licence for a Medicare-eligible magnetic resonance imaging, MRI, machine. Unless the Howard government grants Concord hospital one of the remaining 20 MRI licences that it announced were up for grabs, on 9 June 2004, outpatients from my electorate will continue to be denied reasonable access to this fundamental health service. For two years the Howard government has refused this request. Over and over again the Howard government has denied my constituents, confirming that it does not consider the inner west of Sydney a priority. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (11.17 A.m.)
theText: I again speak on behalf of the Concord RepatriationBefore this week, in nine separate answers to my questions calling for an MRI licence for Concord hospital, recorded in Hansard from 19 August 2002 to 11 May 2004, the government has failed to give any indication that it will grant the licence. You will doubtless recall that last week I reported to the parliament that the Liberal Party has shamelessly tried to deceive my constituents by circulating a leaflet titled ‘MRI machine for our local hospital’ that claims that the Howard government has decided to issue an MRI licence ‘for our local hospital’. I said then that this was no more than a dishonourable attempt to salvage the government’s credibility on this issue by deliberately misleading my constituents. In a report by Evan Mistilis in the Inner West Courier on Monday, 9 August 2004, my Liberal opponent is reported as saying: ... the Federal Government has promised a Medicare funded MRI machine for somewhere in the Inner West. My question No. 3619 on 3 June 2004 asked: Will he grant Concord Hospital a Medicare-funded MRI service before the next federal election ... In the answer I received, recorded in Hansard on Tuesday, 10 August 2004, the Minister for Health and Ageing again failed to guarantee an MRI licence for Concord hospital. Instead, the minister referred to his announcement on 9 June 2004 that 23 Medicare-eligible MRI units would be provided, with: ... 20 to be located in under-serviced areas and hospitals. This process and conditions associated with this expansion are being advertised in the national press. Concord Repatriation General Hospital is able to apply for MBS eligibility in this context. Let it be clear: the minister for health is this week telling me, my constituents and the parliament that no decision has been made about an MRI licence for Concord hospital or the inner west, while my Liberal Party opponent is circulating a leaflet in the electorate of Lowe telling my constituents, ‘The Howard government will issue a licence for an MRI machine for our local hospital,’ and this week told a local newspaper, ‘The federal government has promised a Medicare funded MRI machine for somewhere in the inner west’. As a matter of urgency, my constituents need to find out who is telling the truth. The Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, says that no decision has been made but my Liberal Party opponent says that a promise has been made. Adding insult to injury, in the same answer in Tuesday’s Hansard the health minister confirmed that the government does not consider an MRI licence for Concord a priority, because my constituents already have relatively close access to eight different MRI units, including those at Westmead Hospital, Darcy Road, Westmead; Royal North Shore Public Hospital, St Leonards; North Shore Private Hospital, St Leonards; and Crows Nest Sports Imaging, Pacific Highway, Crows Nest. As I understand it, the health minister does not believe that Concord hospital should receive an MRI licence, because my constituents should be able to go to Westmead, Camperdown, Newtown, St Leonards or Crows Nest. What is galling is that the Liberal Party is telling my constituents that one has already been promised. The only way that my constituents will finally get to the truth about the government’s position is for the minister for health to answer my question on notice No. 3723. I am asking the minister to explain, once and for all, whether a decision to grant Concord hospital an MRI licence has been made. I look forward to his response. MAIN COMMITTEE The government’s position in relation to Concord hospital and the MRI licence has now become a complete farce. The 10,000 petitioners and 130,000 Australians that I represent in Sydney’s inner west, in my electorate of Lowe, deserve nothing less than fair access to the MRI machine to be installed by the Carr government at Concord hospital. That is why the shadow minister for health, Julia Gillard, announced on 20 February this year that a Latham Labor government would immediately grant Concord hospital an MRI licence, and this was echoed by Mark Latham when I took him to the hospital recently. Health: Health Professionals some very positive comments about the health system and health professionals. As we all know, there has been some criticism of the system and health professionals, particularly in New South Wales. In many instances, it has been warranted. However, in fairness to health professionals, I want to speak on their behalf as a person who had an unfortunate accident in November last year. Incidentally, that accident was not as bad as many accidents that other people have had, but it has been an inconvenience to me as a member of parliament who serves his electorate in what I call people-first politics. I initially received treatment at Calvary Hospital in Wagga Wagga from a specialist called Clayton Barnes, who is a resident eye specialist there. Subsequently, I received treatment from various specialists, including Brett O’Donnell, who is a plastic surgeon. The injury that I sustained to my left eye was a very complicated injury. It was described by the specialists that treated me as one of the worse burns they had ever seen. The burns resulted in the destruction of all the muscle tissue as well as in my losing my sight in that eye. At my insistence, rather than lose the eye-because at that stage they did not think I could have a prosthesis-we undertook a very comprehensive, long and tedious program to try to keep the eye in my head and get some cells to grow back over the surface. Unfortunately, despite all the best intentions in the world and a number of operations, that did not occur. But it was not as a result of the way in which the specialists and the hospital staff-including the theatre nurses and other nurses in the hospital-undertook their very professional care, which was magnificent. I could not have asked for better care. In my view, we have the best medical care and the best hospital system in the world. Despite that care and professional advice, I did lose my eye a few weeks back. They grafted more material from my stomach. Prior to that, they grafted mucus membrane from inside my mouth to rebuild the muscle tissue in my eye socket. That just gives you an indication of the skill of these people. When I had my eye removed, they removed some muscle tissue from my lower abdomen and put it into the socket. The end result is, hopefully, that I will have a prosthesis fitted in the next couple of weeks. I made brief mention of the inconvenience of the injury. The inconvenience of the injury was caused because the trauma of losing my eye and the problems that it created affected my good eye, the right eye: I could not judge distance; therefore I could not drive. This situation took my wife away from what she does as a woman in her own right, because I was very heavily reliant on her to drive me around the electorate. After the operation-in fact, within 12 hours of my eye being removed; the mind and body do wonderful things-I could actually feel my eye readjusting. I am now at the point where I want to drive, because I think my eye is okay, but my wife says to me, ‘You couldn’t drive with two eyes, let alone one,’ and she MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Schultz (Hume) (11.22 A.m.)
theText: I rise in this adjournment debate today to voicewill not let me! I am sure I can convince my wife-as we males do from time to time-that I am still useful, and that I will get behind the wheel once again. I would like to take this opportunity also to thank each and every one of my parliamentary colleagues, on all sides of politics, for the concern and interest they have shown in my recovery from my injury. I do appreciate it. It does make you feel better and give you a little bit more confidence in what is happening. I have always tried to make light of what happened to me because I am fully aware that there are people out there with far more serious problems than I have. I have also tried to make my unfortunate accident an example of what it is like when you lose concentration about the process of safety when you are using chemicals. As a result of that, I have had a number of people involved in the chemical industry wanting me to talk to their employees about that, and I would be very happy to do so. Once again, I have taken the opportunity to come into this place and thank my parliamentary colleagues across the broad spectrum of politics for their interest and the concern they have shown to me as an individual. I do appreciate it. Christmas Island: Casino speaker, the member for Hume, and wish him well. I hope he has a full recovery and, at some stage soon, gets to drive his motor vehicle again. Miss Jackie Kelly-His wife doesn’t. to raise a very important issue-that is, the question of a casino licence for Christmas Island. The outgoing Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Roads, Senator Ian Campbell, announced on 17 July that no licence will be issued for the Christmas Island casino. The incoming minister, Mr Lloyd, made comments on ABC radio that the Prime Minister had decided five years ago that gambling was not in the interests of the island’s people. It is now six years since the Christmas Island Resort closed on 23 April 1998. Six years ago the government had the opportunity to act quickly and have the Commonwealth seek expressions of interest from entities wanting to take a lease on the property and apply for a casino licence-which it did. I have here a copy of a letter dated 30 August 1999 from Senator Ian Macdonald, who was then the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, to Mr Herbert, who was the liquidator for the casino, in which he makes it clear that the government was considering, and was concerned, that the casino should be sold on the basis of a casino licence being granted. I seek leave to table that letter. Leave granted. not do that, and led the eventual purchaser of the casino-a company called Soft Star Pty Ltd-to believe that they could develop a new casino operation. That was some six years ago. Earlier this year, in February, the then minister for territories, Senator Ian Campbell, wrote to the community indicating that a casino licence would be contemplated. I have now a letter dated 5 April which Senator Ian Campbell wrote to David Kwon, Managing Director of the Asia Pacific Space Centre, in which he indicated the process for lodging an application for a casino licence. I also have a letter dated 5 April from Senator Ian Campbell to Senator the Hon. Amanda Vanstone as Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Snowdon (Lingiari) (11.27 A.m.)
theText: I acknowledge the contribution of the previous
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Snowdon
theText: His wife doesn’t. The purpose of my addressing this chamber today is
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Snowdon
theText: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth didalso raising the issue of a casino licence and the need for special visas. I seek leave to table those letters. Leave granted. is that the Commonwealth wrote to the Western Australian government and asked if the Western Australian government would take responsibility for regulating casino operations on Christmas Island. We have a proposal from the minister to the Western Australian government to regulate the casino operations; we have letters from the minister to Mr Kwon, the person responsible for Soft Star; and we have a letter from him also to Minister Vanstone. Subsequently, on 14 July, less than a month ago, Senator Campbell wrote to Don O’Donnell, President of the Christmas Island Chamber of Commerce, saying that he had had a meeting with investors who were prepared to put $30 million into reopening the casino. Note the date of that letter: 14 July. Then, on 17 July, the minister put out a press release announcing that the government was no longer prepared to provide a casino licence for Christmas Island and argued: In the interests of the Christmas Island community, the Australian Government has decided to make legislative changes to prohibit casino operations ... What an absolute joke. Without any consultation whatsoever with the Christmas Island community, having led potential investors up the garden path about what they were able and not able to do on Christmas Island, giving guarantees almost to the owners of Soft Star Pty Ltd that they could open a casino, having potential investors and partners to the casino operations come to the island and effectively consummate an agreement with Soft Star Pty Ltd to spend $30 million in its first year of operation, the government then says there will be no casino. Let me tell you, people are very suspicious that someone has put the drip on the government, perhaps another gambling operator. Is there any coincidence with the fact that, at the same time this is happening, PBL is purchasing the casino in Perth in Western Australia? What is going on? This matter was raised in the Sunday Times last week, and I seek leave to table that article. Leave granted. about what is going on and that it is a rort. (Time expired) Condolences: Maddison, Mr Donald Fletcher Maddison as a sugar industry legend was both apt and well deserved. Don Maddison died in Brisbane on 20 June. He was a person of unquestioned integrity, endless enthusiasm and great personal charm. In these days when aspirational advancement is a desired goal, Don Maddison would be seen as a great role model. But the early rungs of his aspirational ladder were not climbed from a silver spoon background, indeed quite the opposite. Don Maddison’s father, who was involved in mining in the Newcastle area, died when he was quite young, leaving three sons. As an aside, a street in Newcastle bears his name. As the youngest of three children, Don was living for a time in his elder brother’s hotel room and he went to school from there, no doubt not the most conducive study environment. That did not impede his progress, nor later when studying at night for tertiary qualifications. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (11.32 A.m.)
theText: The Courier Mail’s description of Donald FletcherFrom there he went to an apprenticeship at BHP, completed a chemical engineering degree at Sydney Tech in 1946 and became a member of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute. At around this time, he married his first wife, Beth Morrison, and had four daughters. His skills in chemical engineering took him to the Nestle Company at Gympie and Sydney, the latter as group manager, before he took on the momentous challenge of turning around the struggling and faction-ridden Tully Sugar Mill in North Queensland. After 10 years of distinguished service at the now well-functioning mill, he moved to Bundaberg as General Manager of the Millaquin Sugar Company, later Bundaberg Sugar, and the Bundaberg Rum Distillery. He was highly respected in the Bundaberg community. It was there that I got to know him well when he took over as chair of the Bundaberg District Tourism and Development Board, the region’s promotion and industry facilitation organisation, covering 11 local authorities. When I became CEO of that body he was my boss, mentor, guide and friend. It was under his leadership that the organisation blossomed and became the envy of like bodies. His business stature, persuasive skills and vision set the body on a firm foundation. But, in his dealings with government, councils and investors, he had an intuitive skill of knowing just how hard to push the boundaries. I well remember when we met those outer boundaries, he had a delightful closure statement: ‘Not even the Archangel Gabriel is going to change that’-and, invariably, he was right. I very much missed his guiding hand on his retirement but he never failed to call and see how I was going, even after I entered politics, on his many trips back to Bundaberg. As a mark of a fulsome life, he was an enthusiast for Apex, Rotary, the Leukaemia Foundation and, in more recent times, Probus and Neighbourhood Watch. He received the highest honours of the sugar industry and his profession, amongst them the Australian Society of Sugar Cane Technologists President’s Medal and the Emeritus Fellowship of the Institute of Engineers. The Bundaberg City Council acknowledged his service to the city by naming Maddison Court on the Bunda Industrial Estate in his honour. He remarried in 1999 and continued to enjoy retirement with his new wife, Allie Sellars, whom he met on a trip to New Zealand. Don Maddison was a devout, though not ostentatious, man with a strong commitment to Christianity and religion. He died in his sleep on 20 June, no doubt leaving a great gap in the lives of his daughters Eleanor, Margaret, Joan and Anne to whom I extend my deepest condolences. No doubt the Archangel Gabriel, whom he took a little lightly and whom he often invoked, was on hand to greet him at the Pearly Gates as a good and faithful servant. Tasmania: Sport turning to sport and our sporting heroes, as they prepare for the world competition. If only our political disputes could be resolved in such a way. I find that the spirit of the Olympics is competitive but also friendly, so just being able to compete in the games is a milestone in itself and, if you win then it is a bonus. It is the road to the games and the friends that you meet on the way that is important. I was excited to learn that a New Norfolk girl has been selected to row in the Australian fours. Her name is Dana Faletic and she is at present a quad scull world champion. Dana was born in Maydena in the south-west of Tasmania. Her father, Mike, is a tree-feller from that district. She has already been in contact with her community from Athens. Her mum is keepMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Adams (Lyons) (11.37 A.m.)
theText: As we approach another Olympics, a lot of minds areing everyone in touch and has told them how to use the Internet to keep up-to-date with the progress of events. I will certainly be doing that, and I wish Dana all the very best. It is marvellous that a woman from the Derwent Valley is out there competing with the best. Sport plays a very important part in the lives of Australians. I guess we just love to be outdoors, the chance of competing and the mateship sport engenders. Tasmania has had many excellent sportspeople who have reached the pinnacle of their careers-cricketers like David Boon and Ricky Ponting, our present captain of the Australian team, are obvious successes. But there are many others who have done extraordinary things in their lives. Another person I would like to talk about is Charles Eady, a cricketer who is now in the Tasmanian sporting hall of fame. Charles was a large, impressive man who performed efficiently for Tasmania as an all-rounder for two decades. But his real claim to fame was his innings of 566 in 473 minutes during a match in Hobart in 1902. He made it in a total of 911 for Break O’Day against Wellington-an incredible score. Eady hit 13 fives and 64 fours and added 429 for the seventh wicket with W. Abbott, who made 143. Play was spread over four afternoons while Eady achieved this. This score remains the highest in club cricket anywhere in the world. He was a tremendous hitter of the ball, but this should not be allowed to overshadow his skill as a bowler. He headed the southern Tasmanian averages four times as a batsman but 12 times as a bowler. He was a true all-rounder. In the 1905-06 season he took all 10 wickets for 42 runs for South Hobart against East Hobart. Eady toured England only once, with the 1896 Australian side, but ill health prevented him from showing his best. He made only 290 runs at an average of 13.18 and took 16 wickets at an average of 25.5. His reputation was secure in his feats at home. Eady, who stood six feet three inches tall and weighed 15 stone, was the first Australian to score a century in each innings of a first class match-a feat he accomplished in the 1894-95 season, when he made 116 and 112 not out against Victoria at Hobart. That is a pretty impressive career, yet he is still not well known outside Tasmania. It is about time that some of the feats of Tasmanian sporting people were recognised more fully. The Tasmanian Sporting Hall of Fame is now remedying that. I am sure that we will hearing more from our Olympian Dana and the many other young people who are coming through their sports to the top. Sport allows youngsters to achieve through their own efforts. They do not have to be academics but, by the same token, to be a top sportsperson you need the grit, stamina and great sense of purpose that take a different sort of intelligence. Let us hope that they are very successful and go on to enjoy a happy and fulfilling life. We wish the best to all of the Australians competing at Athens. Ryan Electorate: Marriage day. I want to speak in support of a topic on which I know the overwhelming majority of the people of my electorate of Ryan will agree with my views and also those of the governmentthat is, the support, promotion and preservation of the institution of marriage. I want to very strongly place on record in parliament my personal support for the government’s intention to legislate in the parliament to support the institution of marriage. I support this very strongly as the federal member for Ryan. I know that there will be some in my electorate who may disagree with me, but I want to say to them with all due respect that, as the MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Johnson (Ryan) (11.42 A.m.)
theText: It is a great pleasure to speak in the parliament torepresentative for the electorate of Ryan, I will be supporting it very strongly. I believe in marriage as an institution. I am a young Australian who has just recently celebrated my second wedding anniversary. I consider it a great honour that someone would share their life with me. I want to place on record some statements by a couple of key associations and organisations in our community which have written to me and which encourage the government to continue on its path in support of the institution of marriage. I want to first place on record a letter from Warwick and Alison Marsh of the Fatherhood Foundation. They write: Dear Michael, We write to thank you for your support for Australian families. They were involved in organising a very large forum here at the parliament last week in which more than 1,000 people participated. Indeed, the Great Hall overflowed last Wednesday, 4 August. Many members and senators joined with organisations like the Fatherhood Foundation and members of the community to support the institution of marriage, celebrate the value of marriage and acknowledge the reinvigoration and revival of this institution. I want to say again very strongly that I support it. Indeed, I want to call on the opposition to support it as well and to be clear and unambiguous about their position. I am also not sure what the position of the local Labor candidate is. There has been no utterance from her about whether she supports the government’s position or which side of the street she walks on in terms of the opposition’s position-whether she supports the shadow spokesman for this area or someone on the Labor Left. For my part, I very strongly support the institution of marriage. I want to again quote from Warwick and Alison Marsh’s letter to me of 10 August, where they say: Thank you again for your support for Australian fathers, families and that time-honoured institution which helps men and women express their love to each other in the deepest possible way. Your support for marriage will help our families stay connected and together. The mothers, fathers and children of Australia appreciate your support. that statement. I will certainly make it very clear to the people of Ryan that Labor members here are very strongly interjecting to the contrary in the parliament, and no doubt that will be reflected in the coming election. terjections. Muslim Public Affairs Committee, because they have put out a statement very strongly supporting the government and members of the government who are particularly active in this field of endeavour. They say: … the Australian Muslim community believes that the protection of marriage is imperative. We praise the efforts of our government to enshrine in law what is enshrined in common-sense and human experience over the ages: that if the family is the building-block of society, then the marriage of man and wife is its mortar. We must not sacrifice our most critical social institution on the altar of political correctness. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Johnson
theText: I also want to speak in the parliament, on the record, of the AustralianTo that I say, ‘Hear, hear!’ I will be going on Sunday to a City West Church service, to the Australian National Day of Honour that they are putting on throughout the country, where they will be saying prayers for the leadership of our country and our community. I want to thank very much Pastor Dallas Freeman of City West Church for his invitation. It will be a great honour for me to be a guest at Kenmore State High School on Sunday, 15 August, where I will be able to meet many members of the Ryan community. Elections: Minor Parties candidate for Wentworth, Malcolm Turnbull, tell a public meeting that history would judge the war on Iraq as an error. Of course he was right. We need to look back at how this came about. In the coming month or so, we will be facing a federal election, but in November there will also be an election in the largest and most powerful nation on earth-the United States of America. Last time that election took place, George Bush was elected as the President of the United States, with a minority of votes counted but also with a significant dispute over the votes in Florida. One of the issues that was relevant for that result was that it was not just a contest between George Bush of the Republican Party and Al Gore of the Democrats; there was a third candidate-the Green Party leader, Ralph Nader, ran in the election. In Florida, Ralph Nader polled more than 95,000, or more than two per cent, of the votes. Across the nation, he polled between two and three per cent. Exit polls in Colorado, Nevada, New Hampshire, Oregon, Washington state and Wisconsin suggest that a considerable majority of those people who voted for Ralph Nader would have preferred Al Gore to be the President of the United States if it were a two-horse race. It is quite clear that, had Ralph Nader not run in the ballot, Al Gore would have been elected President of the United States in 2000. If Al Gore had been elected President of the United States in 2000, it is clear that he would have had a very different attitude towards the United Nations processes and towards international relations in the wake of 9-11, the tragedy that struck the United States. It is quite clear that we would have had a very different international environment from the one that we face today. Ralph Nader said: I did not run for President to help elect one or the other of the two major candidates. You can’t spoil a system spoiled to the core. I do not think democracy is spoiled to the core. I think democracy is the greatest system that we have and we need to acknowledge what people’s role is in that democracy. Ralph Nader and those people who supported him, such as the Australian Greens, and who are supporting him running again in 2004 could make the difference and ensure that George Bush is re-elected to the White Housepoint. The Greens, through their candidature of Ralph Nader, assist the process of a rightwing Republican regime in the United States, just as here in Australia the Greens spend most of their time attacking the Labor Party, attacking progressives who are closest to them in MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (11.47 A.m.)
theText: This week we have seen the Liberal Party

theText: Hear, hear!

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: ‘Hear, hear!’ says the Liberal member opposite. Exactly-that is myterms of their ideological position and, through that consistent attack, end up undermining the overall strength of progressive politics in this country. Liberal Party went and handed out for the Greens in Cunninghamto interjections. Liberals will be extending preferences to the Greens in my electorate because they would prefer a Greens candidate to be elected rather than a Labor candidate. We need to be very clear about what we are doing when we look at the exercise of democracy and we need to examine what the real impact was of Ralph Nader running in 2000 and what damage he could cause in ensuring that George Bush is re-elected in 2004. (Time expired) Defence: Personnel Labor Party over its policy on defence. It is very appropriate that here this morning we have two parliamentary secretaries, one who has had a long-time association with the Australian Defence Force and another who has a new but very important association with the Australian Defence Force. They will know, as I do, that Labor’s policy to cut 3,000 civilian jobs in defence is nothing short of disgraceful. In my electorate in Townsville, where I have Australia’s largest Army base and a very significant RAAF base, we have 564 civilians providing much-needed support service to the ADF to allow ADF members to do the work that they are there to do-to be on guard, ready to respond, ready to look after Australia’s interests. But the opposition spokesman on defence announced yesterday that 3,000 civilian jobs are to go. What is going to happen in Townsville, where we have both Australian Public Service and defence contractors on bases? These people are performing senior management roles, clerical and administration support, dealing with personnel and HR issues and giving pay and accounts advice. They include facilities people and engineers. They provide infrastructure support, information technology systems support and financial management. The contractors do access security, patrols around the perimeter of bases, grounds maintenance, cleaning, running of messes and accommodation facilities and maintenance of the built infrastructure. Labor’s policy is to take serving men and women of the Australian Defence Force, in uniform, and put them into these sorts of jobs. That is a disastrous policy and that is a policy that I will resist to my last breath. The current government has spent significant resources moving members of the Defence Force to the sharp end. The men and women of the Defence Force in Townsville-particularly the men of the 1st Battalion of the Royal Australian Regiment, currently Australia’s ready deployment battalion-are ready to respond anywhere in the world within 24 hours. But how are they going to keep up that professionalism if they are out there manning gates, mowing the lawn, fixing a leaking tap somewhere or driving a desk? It is not right. This comes from a shadow minister who believes, of all things, that we should not have chocolate bars in Australian Defence Force ration packs. He just does not understand the Defence Force. This is the shadow minister who, when he was finance minister, oversaw the axMAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Lindsay (Herbert) (11.52 A.m.)
theText: I propose to comprehensively attack the Australianing of two full-time infantry battalions as a cost-saving measure. It was only the coalition which reinstated those battalions-fortunately-to enable the ADF to be ready for the challenges of East Timor. Let me say quite specifically that I believe the agenda of the Australian Labor Party is to cease having overseas deployment for members of the Australian Defence Force. Labor obviously does not understand the Defence Force. The people in the Defence Force spend their entire working lives training to be ready to deploy, and it is these overseas deployments that hone the skills of our Defence Force and make sure that they are ready to go when they are really needed. I have seen first-hand the wonderful things that the men and women of the Australian Defence Force have been able to do in recent years on overseas deployments. I have seen them in East Timor and I have seen them in the Solomon Islands. You have people from those countries coming up to you and saying: ‘You’re an Australian. We want to thank you for bringing back safety, security, peace and stability to our country.’ It is the men and women of the Australian Defence Force, highly trained people, who do that and make sure in Australia’s name that we are able to help our neighbours. But we are not going to be able to do that if the Australian Labor Party has its way. We will be sending a battalion of cleaners over to the Solomons or East Timor. I am not going to stand for that. I want the people of my electorate to know and understand what it would mean if ever the Australian Labor Party were elected back to government. Shortland Electorate: Medicare Office Ms HALL (Shortland) (11.57 a.m.)-I rise today to implore the government to reopen the Medicare office at Belmont. This is an issue that I have raised in the House on numerous occasions. I raised it the first time when I made my first speech in the House on 11 November 1998. I raised it again on 12 November 1998, when I pointed out the difficulties that people living in Shortland electorate have in accessing the Medicare offices that are currently available to them. I raised the issue again on 5 September, after we had a public meeting at Swansea and the people who attended that public meeting raised it as an issue. On 26 February 2001 I again raised the issue of how the Medicare office had been closed and how it had been one of the busiest Medicare offices in New South Wales. I pointed out that the nearest Medicare offices were at Lake Haven on the Central Coast and at Charlestown. I also pointed out that there was a high pensioner population in the area and that a number of people who lived in the electorate or nearby really were elderly. On 19 March 2002 I again raised the issue of the Belmont Medicare office and pointed out that the staff at the Charlestown Medicare office had identified it as the single most important issue relating to Medicare in the area. On 11 August 2003, I raised it again and I put it in the context of the decline in bulk-billing. To date, the government have not acted on this. The people of Shortland electorate are being penalised by their inaction. I implore them to reconsider their decision and to reopen the Medicare office at Belmont. I seek leave to table a question that I put to the former minister for health, Minister Wooldridge, which contained a number of questions about the closure of the Medicare office. Leave granted. MAIN COMMITTEE The former member for Shortland submitted petitions with 14,150 signatures calling for the reopening of the Medicare office. I have submitted 6,000 signatures. During the last sitting week, I submitted 1,372 signatures, and I have with me another nearly 700 signatures. This is an enormous issue for the people I represent in the electorate of Shortland. Shortland is the 10th ‘oldest’ electorate in Australia. Living there are a number of elderly people who do not have driver’s licences or who have restricted licences which allow them to drive as far as Belmont. Unfortunately, if they do not have a licence or if their restricted licence limits them to driving to Belmont, they cannot drive to the Medicare office at Charleston or the Medicare office at Lake Haven, and it will therefore take them up to an hour-or in some cases longer-to get to a Medicare office. At a time when fewer doctors are bulkbilling, this has created a real problem for them. Many of the people who need to access a Medicare office need to get an immediate refund to enable them to purchase their medication. I feel that it is heartless of the Howard government to ignore the needs of the people I represent. It is not that the Medicare office did not have a substantial number of people using it. It is not that the staff did not recognise the fact that the Medicare office was of vital importance. No, it was none of those things. I think the only thing that determined that the Medicare office at Belmont be closed was the fact that it was in a Labor electorate. I implore the government to reconsider their decision, because this is an issue of vital importance to the people I represent in this parliament. Social Welfare: Debt Ms KING (Ballarat) (12.03 p.m.)-I rise in the adjournment debate to highlight yet again the impact of the Howard government’s mismanagement of social security debts. On the eve of the release of Audit report No. 4 of 2004-05, Management of customer debt, the government sought to deflect criticism by announcing a review of the debt recovery arm of Centrelink, but it was too little too late and was an inadequate response to what the Audit Office itself has said is a pretty damning report. The Auditor-General revealed in his report that nearly $1 billion in overpayments and debts had been racked up, an amount that excludes the $500 million generated by the flawed family benefit system. I am appalled that the Audit Office found that the irresponsible practice of not only offering credit cards as a repayment option but listing it as the first option available on the Centrelink web site did not stop even after the government publicly stated that it did. I am appalled because the practice came to light as a result of a complaint by one of my constituents, and I naively believed the government when it said that the practice had stopped. The Audit Office also found that the government’s management and recovery of debt were inconsistent and that the government collected no information about the impact of their debt management and recovery system on individuals. The government can give no assurance that people are not being placed in real financial hardship as a result of their practices. Only a small proportion of debts are created by deliberate fraud. The vast majority of debts are caused by the complex nature of our social security system. In recent months, we have seen the continuation of the flawed family payment system. We have seen the government’s clawback on age pensions and the extraordinary double standards shown by the government in applying a different standard to families paid two lots of the government’s election bribe while cracking down on age pensioners, the disabled and carers. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Ms Hall
theText: To date, numerous petitions on this issue have been submitted to the House.Back in June, Senate estimates figures showed that the Howard government had raised almost $39 million of Centrelink debts against more than 15,000 pensioners. The government may not collect information about the financial hardship its debt management and recovery system people in Australia but we do, because we see it on a weekly basis in our electorate offices. Currently in the cases I have before my office we have the government trying to claw back $85,635 from aged pensioners, $21,000 from the disabled, $37,899 in family tax benefits and $39,488 from students and young people. That is a total of $184,022 from my electorate alone-and these are just the cases that we know about and that are current. The worse case I have is the case of a couple on the age pension. The debt that the government claims they owe was not brought about by deliberate fraud; it has come about because the government failed to conduct basic annual checks of partners’ income. In this case, one person was on the age pension and the other had casual employment. They informed Centrelink of their income and provided income tax returns on request. The person on the age pension had never received a full age pension and their pension fluctuated, but, because the government failed to match the income information provided by them with Centrelink data on an annual basis, they have incurred a debt. If they had been told of the debt in the first year, I have no doubt at all they would have repaid the money and the problem would not have occurred again. Both of them are now on an age pension. The initial bill the couple received from the government was a massive $30,000. The government has now, after a wait of over five weeks, given them their first ARO review. In my view, this system is designed to automatically knock people back and dissuade them from further pursuing the matter. They have now been told their combined debt is $35,000. The couple are incredibly distraught by being faced with this level of debt at this time of their lives. Despite being part of the way through their appeal process and having sought a waiver from the parliamentary secretary, they have had to start their repayments. They are frankly mortified by the situation they find themselves in. Further examples in my office include a 66-year-old who received an overpayment from Centrelink of $16,000. While her daughter contacted Centrelink and was informed that it was okay, Centrelink immediately automatically withdrew from her bank account $8,000, the balance of that account. Another lady received a debt of over $7,500 due to CPI increases in her Netherlands part pension. Failure by the government to data match and make adjustments has seen her have to repay over $5,000 of that money. In relation to family tax benefit, I had the case of a woman receiving an overpayment of $1,000, despite declaring her regular income. I have also had cases of couples being told to repay on credit card. Is it any wonder that this audit report found that the government’s debt management system is inconsistent, in some cases heavy handed and unable to ascertain whether the government’s debt recovery activities place people in real financial hardship? We know they do place people in real financial hardship. The review announced by the minister is totally inadequate. The system needs reform. Lindsay Electorate Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay-Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (12.08 p.m.)-Under the Commonwealth’s Roads to Recovery program, Penrith City Council has received $3.637 million over the life of the project from 2001 to 2005. So far, only $2.879 million has been spent. Therefore over $757,000 remains to be spent in the financial year MAIN COMMITTEE 2004-05 on specific programs via council application. One of the projects I recommend to council is Chain of Ponds Road. I have received a petition from a number of concerned residents regarding the dangerous intersection into Chain of Ponds Road from Northern Road within my electorate. It is a very bad accident waiting to happen. There is no space to wait on Northern Road while you are turning and there is certainly no through lane so that traffic backing up behind you can swing to the left and get past you. This encourages motorists to overtake from behind cars, possibly collecting a car turning right or, with oncoming cars, causing some dire accidents. There have been a number of very near misses, according to my constituents. It is an area that needs some attention. Whether it needs to be as serious as lights or just a widening of the road at that point to two lanes to incorporate a turning lane is up to road specialists to determine. But something certainly needs to be done in that area before an accident occurs. A place which has seen numerous accidents-this is not an accident waiting to happen; accidents have occurred on a regular basis-is at the intersection of Mulgoa Road, Spencer Street and School House Road. It is a very crowded intersection. The residents exiting Regentville or Glenmore Park, in my area, come along Mulgoa Road and have School House Road to the right, coming down from a very busy and large primary school, and Spencer Street on the left. Again, there is not sufficient room for cars backed up waiting to turn, and motorists on the inside lack a clear enough field of vision to make a good judgment of when to turn. We have seen a number of instances when cars have turned across one lane of traffic, and the second lane of traffic has not seen the turning car and has collected them on the way through. There have been several very nasty accidents already at that intersection. Another area of concern is Old Church Lane. It has been turned into a dead end with the lakes development, and that has caused much consternation to the constituents along the road. Again, I have received a number of petitions from residents in that area. I would like to see an upgrade of that road, as well as police attention to the road because it seems to be a loitering area for vandals. Another place council can pay its attention to-because the council does charge our ratepayers outrageously, and recently we have seen a 30 per cent rise in council fees for some ratepayers-is near Kingswood railway station. There is an uncovered portion of pipeline there that is running parallel to Park Road in Kingswood. It is an unusual part of the pipeline to be exposed. All along that area there are units. It is a very high-density living area, and something as unsavoury as that pipeline needs to be covered. I have yet to mention the inordinate number of footpaths that are still to be built around our area. I notice that the Liberal councillors on Penrith City Council have been making good efforts in this area and in the last few years have upped the amount that council spends on footpaths, but there is still a significant number of footpaths that need to be put around our area. The money was placed with council when developments went ahead, so that council could come back later and put in the footpaths once all the driveways were in place in the various subdivisions, but council seems to have pocketed the money and left residents without footpaths. That money should be used now and council should hurry and start putting those footpaths down around our new subdivisions. Other things that council could be working on include the beautification of the Jamison Park area, Grey Gums Oval and Tench Reserve, to create some lovely walking tracks around MAIN COMMITTEE our area so that when our residents do finally get on the new footpaths they can go down the end of their street to a really nice walking area-which would also fit into the government’s healthy living plan and obesity in schools program. Early Childhood Ms O’BYRNE (Bass) (12.13 p.m.)-Approaching nine years in government, what can the Prime Minister and those on the opposite side claim as anything like a national strategy for early childhood? Labor quite rightly places the early years of every life on the first rung of the ladder of opportunity. A working partnership between the Commonwealth and the states and territories on the vast array of issues which affect the early years must be a priority of the highest order. When the member for Werriwa became the Leader of the Opposition he demonstrated most emphatically Labor’s commitment to proper and adequate support for a national strategy for early childhood development. His first question in the House as leader was about just that. He asked why the government had no early childhood strategy. We failed to get an answer then and we have seen virtually nothing of substance since. It took until earlier this month-almost nine long years after Howard and his ministers took office-for something to appear, and then the best they could manage was a dollar-free draft national agenda for early childhood. On the other hand, it is not a theme that we have forgotten. Once again it is Labor with the ideas, Labor creating the agenda, Labor showing that it understands what Australians need. Read Aloud Australia, an assault on childhood obesity, support for community playgroups, acceptance of the recommendations of the experts on infant vaccinations, and a commissioner for children and young people form the beginning of Labor’s plan for early childhood development. While the government muddles and engages in the odd bit of rhetoric, we on this side of the House are listening and responding to the needs of the parents of the youngest Australians. The recent framework announced by the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs is the government’s first attempt, despite being in power since 1996, to engage the states and territories on childhood issues. One of my organisations, the Child Health Association, recently wrote to the Minister for Family and Community Services about the lack in many parts of the country of parenting facilities-clean and easy-to-access feeding and changing areas for babies and accessible toilets for young children, regardless of the gender of the parent or carer with them at the time. What became of the letter? It was referred to the department, who said, ‘No, it’s not our problem; it is all to do with the state department.’ Why? Because this government has no strategy for dealing with the issues-no compact with states and territories, no plan to ensure that the role of families is well regarded in the community. Labor do have a plan, and we will work with the states to ensure that we develop good strategies for children and families. The first five years of a child’s life are absolutely critical to development. Learning does not begin when a child first enters school; it starts on the first day of life. All governments must be receptive to the needs of parents and be prepared to partner them in ensuring that children have the best possible start in life. Community playgroups, mostly run by voluntary committees of parents and grandparents, play a valuable role in this regard, and we believe they deserve more support. We believe that the government ought to partner these groups through targeted provision of additional resources. The Leader of the Opposition in a recent speech drew attention to international studies which have shown that it is possible to predict a child’s opportunities in life by the age of five. This demonstrates the absolute importance of a MAIN COMMITTEE real and working Australian agenda for early childhood development. Every Australian child deserves the opportunity of a fair go in life. If, as has been indicated, those first five years are so critical then they need a range of supportive and supported environments in their own homes, at child care centres, in playgroups and at preschool. Australia’s younger citizens deserve to be supported, engaged and challenged in appropriate ways. They need opportunities to interact with other children and adults in friendly circumstances. For too long the ideologies of those opposite have left all of these issues to look after themselves, but the reality is that failure to invest in the earliest years is a recipe for lower education, fewer social opportunities and lower standards for those who miss out. The words of the Treasurer urging Australians to populate have a hollow ring when one takes time to reflect on what the government has planned for each newborn’s first five years-essentially nothing. The other area that I wish to discuss is to do with the ABC’s commercial arm, ABC Enterprises. While I am fully aware that it is not parliament’s role to determine what the ABC should broadcast and the nature of ABC programming, I am particularly concerned that ABC Enterprises may have been handed the power and authority to make the judgment on what Australian children will see on television. The ABC children’s television department has quite rightly been feted over time for its knowledge and expertise. It has made a substantial contribution to the education and enjoyment of countless young Australians. It is therefore very disappointing that the ABC now appears to have become beholden to the commercial dollar. Sadly this is even evident in the area of children’s television. It seems that the programs our children will in future see on ABC television will be determined by the marketability and profitability of spin-off products such as videos, DVDs, books, toys and other merchandise. Marketing should not become the primary consideration of an organisation such as the ABC. The recent advertisement by ABC Enterprises for expressions of interest in developing a program for toddlers or slightly older girls was accompanied by the rider that the program should be commercially saleable intellectual property for the ABC. The advertisement further required the program to have broad international potential in respect of both TV program sales and ancillary rights exploitation. These outcomes are fine as flow-on benefits but, as I have said before, they should not be the primary consideration. The development of children’s minds and thoughts are too important for that. The ABC, as an independent broadcaster, has a terribly important role in children’s television. One key aspect has been its ability and capacity to place other issues ahead of commercial considerations. This ought not change. Defence Industry: Tenix Ms GAMBARO (Petrie)-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence) (12.18 p.m.)-I am privileged to be speaking today regarding the historic signing-which I had the pleasure of attending the other night-of the $500 million contract between Tenix and New Zealand for Project Protector. While that is terrific news for the New Zealand government, it is also terrific news for Australian companies of the high calibre of Tenix. Tenix is one of the top 50 defence companies in the world and it employs some 3,000 people in locations throughout Australia and the Asia-Pacific region. It is involved in a number of areas that benefit Australian jobs and provide very valuable support to our defence industries. Those areas are aerospace, land and marine, and electronic. MAIN COMMITTEE The Aerospace Division was established in 1998. It provides support to the Australian defence forces and employs 170 personnel. It is a very specialised area that provides design for a number of defence aircraft. Its standards are very good; it delivers world’s best practice. The Aerospace Division is also ISO 9001 approved. It does all sorts of terrific things such as system design, aircraft integration, development of ground flight and systems tests, and logistical support. The Land Division employs a large number of Australian employees in Wingfield in Adelaide and also in areas such as the Albury-Wodonga region. Both sides are capable of managing production activities. In particular, the Bandiana site manages the garrison support side of things and the logistical part that is so very important. The marine aspect, though, is perhaps the one we hear about the most, particularly when we are talking about frigates and the ability of companies of high calibre, such as Tenix, to deliver the frigates on time, which they do. They deliver as per their contract on time and in a professional manner. The Marine Division, a newly formed division, has shipbuilding in Western Australia and naval systems in Victoria and is the central point of contact for Commonwealth Defence managers of marine projects combining west coast and east coast activities. The particular vessels that were launched the other night will perform very valuable work in fishing and protection activities. It is with that in mind that the Australian government will be watching very closely the success of the New Zealand contract. The Marine Division also has some operating facilities located at Henderson in Western Australia. It is very important that that construction, repair and maintenance work continue. The Rockingham site in Western Australia and the Williamstown site in Victoria provide inservice support activities, and other support facilities are located in Darwin in the Northern Territory and at the World Trade Centre in Melbourne. This company has grown. We should be very proud of our Australian companies and the support that they provide. There are many locations around the world where Tenix is also placed, and it delivers to other countries quality services in providing tenders and very good services such as shipbuilding services. Another area that is extremely important is the electronic systems area, an area that Tenix has also been involved in. It provides systems engineering and integration, design, development, installation, test, manufacture and all kinds of electronic software, electro-optics, mechanical and aeronautical systems. That is extremely important, particularly when you are dealing with simulation, electronic warfare, command, control and communication, and surveillance and reconnaissance. I know that the Australian defence forces will benefit from much of the logistical work that is being done by the company, and I know that the technology in this country and our innovations are something that we can be truly proud of. There are many companies that are providing services for our defence forces that provide us with top technological standards and innovation. I want to say one last thing before I close. The Tenix Group have had a very successful and very dynamic impact on this country, and they will continue to provide this very valuable assistance and support. I congratulate them on their latest milestone. I know that they will continue to be a world-class defence supply company into the future. (Time expired) MAIN COMMITTEE Defence: Military Justice Minister for Defence that Labor are also pleased that Tenix has won the Project Protector contract. I also ask the parliamentary secretary whether she is proud of the way the Navy and her ministerial colleague have treated A, the executive officer of HMAS Stirling, an outstanding and distinguished female officer of the Department of Defence who has been hounded out of the Navy. I ask the parliamentary secretary whether, in the case of A and Dr David McKenzie, she would make a full statement about the circumstances surrounding the case. Would she has a question. Will the member for Chifley allow a question? Miss Jackie Kelly-I ask the member why he did not ask those questions during the parliamentary secretary’s speech. Zealand. I understood about the project. In the case of Dr David McKenzie, the WA Medical Board inquiry has found, in the particulars issue, him guilty of everyMs Gambaro-I am just replying. Ms Gambaro-No. speech. I think this is a very serious matter. You have ruined the careerchair. in ADFA and had looked forward to a career. There was, if not a conspiracy, a concerted attempt between the CO of Stirling and this doctor to have this woman discharged as being medically unfit. Madam Deputy Speaker, how would you feel if you were in A’s position and went to your doctor on base reporting a cold and a headache and were referred to a psychiatrist? I ask the parliamentary secretary: given that in answers to questions you do not know what the particulars are of the case made by the WA Medical Board inquiryMs Gambaro-Yes. to pay Dr McKenzie’s expenses when they did not know what the charges were against them? That is on the public record. How do you determine when you are going to defend a doctor if you do not even know what the charges are? That is on the public record. It is on the Hansard. What criteria, Parliamentary Secretary, do you use to determine whether or not you are going MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Price
theText: No. I think I have been more than generous. How did the department decideto fund a case? I ask, Parliamentary Secretary: why was every avenue of internal redress proved to be unsuccessful but, as soon as you have got an independent external body-the WA Medical Board inquiry-it unanimously finds the doctor is guilty of a whole range of professional misconduct? This is the same doctor who was on the HMAS Kanimbla and who gave injections to those ratings and servicemen that were sent to the Middle East. Remember that controversy? This is a doctor who is found guilty of not being able to maintain a professional confidence of a patient. Is there any rating or soldier that has suffered as a result of you and the department deliberately secreting this doctor away to the Middle East so he could not face these charges? I think these are reasonable questions to ask. It is very good for the parliamentary secretary to be proud about the ship contract, but what about how it affects personnel-how a distinguished naval officer, who is entitled to look to a career where she probably would have reached the rank of rear admiral, has had her career destroyed? We do not hear a word out of the minister; we do not hear a word out of the parliamentary secretary. Why won’t you make a full statement? Why won’t you make a ministerial statement about this case? through the chair. BeforeI call the next speaker, I should say that I have inadvertently caused some distress amongst the clerks. Apparently intervention is not in order during an adjournment debate-so that will not be allowed in the future. Foreign Affairs: Taiwan about the talking up of tensions across the Taiwan Strait and the belligerence that was being adopted in certain areas on that. I was interested to read in the Weekend Australian of 7 and 8 August quite a large feature, headed up ‘Storms on the strait’. That article states: Sino-Taiwanese relations-edgy at the best of times-have deteriorated following the re-election in May of President Chen Shui-bian who has promised to adopt a new constitution for Taiwan in 2008-a move that Beijing sees as tantamount to an act of self-determination. The article also states: China’s state-run newsagency Xinhua quoted ... minister Cao Gangchuan as pledging that the 2.5 million-strong Chinese military would crush any attempt at independence by Taiwan. The article further stated: “For Taiwan, Beijing’s rhetoric and a belligerence reflected in a build-up of missiles are creating an increasingly tense situation-and a self-defeating stance,” noted the Financial Times. “Threats from Beijing have always antagonised Taiwan, widening the divide across the strait.” As I said in my previous contribution, why is the PRC talking up this tension across the Taiwan Strait? Why all of a sudden is the PRC getting edgy about this? They point to the Taiwanese elections. No doubt the PRC would point to Taiwanese elections-they do not have much experience of elections themselves. But there was a proper, fair and democratic election in Taiwan in May of this year. There had previously been an election in Taiwan where President Chen was elected and he was re-elected in May this year. As I said in my previous contribution, there was a lot of talk in Taiwan amongst the various political parties about what the outcome of the election would be and whether there was a proindependence position. Indeed, the people who did most of the talking up, saying that PresiMAIN COMMITTEE
