speaker: Mr Leo Mcleay (Watson) (12.28 P.m.)
theText: Recently in this chamber I raised a questiondent Chen’s party was in favour of independence, were the old KMT regime. They left China in the forties and still pretended, right up until they were defeated by President Chen and the democratic forces in Taiwan-they pretended right up until this century-that they were still the government of China. Now they have changed their tack and they maintain that President Chen is interested in having independence. The interesting thing that people should do, as I said in my last contribution, is go back to what President Chen said at his inauguration. At the inauguration of the President and Vice President on 20 May this year, the President said that Taiwan was going to get into a constitutional re-engineering project. He said that that project’s aims were to enhance good governance and increase administrative efficiency to ensure a solid foundation for the democratic rule of law, and to foster long-term stability and prosperity of the nation. He went on to say: There are many problems in our current Constitution that need to be tackled, amongst which the more immediate and obvious include: whether to have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power; whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government; whether the president should be elected by a relative majority or an absolute majority; reform of the national legislature and relevant articles; the role of the National Assembly and its retainment versus abolishment; whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government; lowering of voting age; modification of compulsory military service requirements; protection of basic human rights and the rights of the disadvantaged; and, principles governing the running of the national economy. Indeed, this will be a project of grand scale that is certain to have significant impact. But he went on to say that there was a great non-issue. He said: In the same context, I am fully aware that consensus has yet to be reached on issues related to national sovereignty, territory and the subject of unification/independence; therefore, let me explicitly propose that these particular issues be excluded from the present constitutional re-engineering project. It could not be any more plain. The President of Taiwan is not talking about independence. The PRC are beating this up for reasons known only to them. (Time expired) Capricornia Electorate: Shoalwater Bay Ms LIVERMORE (Capricornia) (12.34 p.m.)-It has always been my belief that the most important job of a member of parliament is to be the voice of his or her community in the parliament. I am here as the voice of the people of Central Queensland and as a link between them and the government. Right now the people of Central Queensland, particularly those living on the Capricorn Coast, have a message for the Howard government about the plans it has for Shoalwater Bay. On their behalf I am asking the Minister for Defence for some answers. Shoalwater Bay, just 80 kilometres north of the city of Rockhampton, is a special part of my electorate for a number of reasons. To many Central Queenslanders lucky enough to get out on the water and explore it, Shoalwater Bay is a spectacular natural treasure with miles of beaches and clear blue waters reaching out to the Great Barrier Reef. We are also well aware of Shoalwater Bay’s other purpose and the important role it plays in the defence of Australia. The Shoalwater Bay training area has been managed by the Australian Defence Force since 1965. It is recognised as one of Australia’s premier defence training areas, encompassing 270,000 hectares of land and 180,000 hectares of marine reserve. Apart from its size, it has enormous value to Defence because it is the only place in Australia where the Navy, Army and Air Force can engage in joint exercises involving all three MAIN COMMITTEE forces as well as forces from other countries. We in Central Queensland have always been pleased to play our role as host to the visiting forces of our allies, such as the Singaporeans and the Americans, when they have stayed in our region to take part in joint exercises up at Shoalwater Bay. The large joint exercises bring welcome dollars into our businesses large and small. The soldiers spend up big in Rockhampton and Yeppoon when they are on leave, and many other local businesses have taken the initiative and geared up their operations to support defence activities in our region. It is because we have always been so supportive of these joint exercises in the past that the people of Central Queensland are so angry and concerned about the treatment they have received from the defence minister since his announcement on 8 July this year that the US and Australian governments had agreed to develop a joint combined training centre. The minister’s statement identified Shoalwater Bay as a key part of that plan. The minister’s statement refers to Shoalwater Bay as one of the sites in Australia to be ‘further developed and able to be linked with American facilities’. He said: Our initial priority will be to upgrade the Shoalwater Bay facility to support the first of the Talisman Sabre series of biennial joint training exercises that will be undertaken in 2007 ... He went on: Talisman Sabre will see tens of thousands of Australian and US military personnel undertake land, sea and air training in operations such as full-scale amphibious landing, airstrike bomb runs using live munitions as well as high-tech computer simulated scenarios. If you will pardon the pun, Mr Deputy Speaker, that news hit Central Queensland like a bombshell. Shoalwater Bay is in our backyard, and here was the Australian government making plans for it with no consideration or acknowledgement of what it might mean for the local community and the fact that we might have liked to be consulted on its impact before hearing about it on the nightly news. The minister’s statement aroused significant concern throughout the Central Queensland community-concern which only grew as the weeks passed and still no answers came from Minister Hill to clarify exactly what was planned for Shoalwater Bay. What about the local roads surrounding Shoalwater Bay? Will Livingstone Shire ratepayers continue to foot the bill for their maintenance and repair following exercises, or does the government plan to pay its fair share? What about the significant environmental value of Shoalwater Bay-are there guarantees that it will be protected? Does this mean troops will be permanently based in Central Queensland? Minister Hill’s failure to engage with our community and share the details of the government’s plan was an insult to a community that has given loyal and patriotic support to joint exercises that we recognise as a vital part of preparations for our nation’s security. The Morning Bulletin newspaper in Rockhampton summed up the feeling in the community in its editorial on 21 July, entitled ‘What is Howard trying to hide?’ It said: We’re not happy being treated like second class citizens over the Shoalwater Bay defence force agreement. Our entire community is angry and insulted that our federal government is hiding from us information which we more than anyone else in the country have a right to know. Finally, on 29 July we got some reassurance from the minister in his statement confirming that ‘the US is not seeking to base forces in Australia’. But questions are still being raised by the Capricorn Coast community and its representatives. I have written to the minister on their MAIN COMMITTEE behalf, asking, among other things, that he release full details of the agreement signed with the US government and that he answer questions such as what measures will be put in place to deal with the social impact of any upgrade, whether Shoalwater Bay will be permanently closed, whether the US will want sovereignty of the area, what capital input will be involved and what funding will be provided for the necessary infrastructure. I want those answersand, more importantly, the people of Central Queensland deserve those answers. Health and Ageing: Aged Care not have in their electorates aged care facilities and, in particular, retirement villages that service the needs of those who have moved from their own homes and live independently, some for long periods of time, in arrangements that allow them some flexibility in their lives. The residents of these places do not require accommodation in aged care facilities specifically designed for those who cannot care for themselves, and they have entered into these arrangements on the understanding and expectation that they would not be subjected to the impost of the GST in relation to the service fees and costs associated with their accommodation. The reason why they had that expectation was that there was an explicit commitment given by the coalition government before the introduction of the GST that it would exclude retirement village residents. Sadly, there has been an ongoing area of uncertainty because of the way in which the Australian Taxation Office has been flagging that many of the services and costs related to the provision of aged care services to those in independent retirement will in fact now be impacted by the GST. On Tuesday, I think it was, the Treasurer was asked by the shadow Treasurer, in relation to these particular services, whether or not GST was going to be charged by the Australian Taxation Office. The Treasurer told the parliament that retirement village residents in serviced apartments and independent living units are not GST-free-a direct contradiction of the pledge that they would be free of GST made by the coalition before the introduction of the GST. Yesterday, I understand, the Prime Minister expressed the view that they were in fact going to be GST-free. The problem is that the administrative arrangements that are being pursued by the tax office have not been suspended as a consequence, and those who are living in those independent serviced units and retirement villages rather than aged care facilities as such still believe, rightly, that their costs may now be the subject of additional GST. I have been approached by a number of people in my electorate who are very concerned about this. I have been unable to provide them with any assurances in relation to this. When I pursued it, I found that there was no answer. It caused some difficulties for me because I was unable to provide a clear explanation to my constituents. I feel rather embarrassed about it, but I understand now that the reason why I was unable to find out and give clear answers was that the government itself is pursuing two diametrically opposite approaches. The Treasurer is saying that they will be the subject of GST and the Prime Minister is saying that they will not. The Taxation Office is pursuing arrangements in line with the Treasurer’s instructions and is looking for arrangements as to how the GST will be applied. My constituents are entitled to clarity, particularly before the next election. They are entitled to me being able to provide them with a clear answer and I am entitled, I believe, to be able to provide them with that clear answer. Thus far I am not able to do so. I find that extremely disconcerting-much less disconcerting, I am certain, than the residents in, for examMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Kerr (Denison) (12.39 P.m.)
theText: There would be few members in the House who dople, the large retirement facilities that are just next to the primary school near where I grew up in Claremont and Cadburys Estate. That place provides accommodation for many people who are entitled to a secure understanding of their future. I would like to be able to give it to them. Sadly, I am not able to. I hope this issue is clarified by the end of this parliamentary sitting week because, if it is not, all around Australia there are going to be thousands, if not tens of thousands, of elderly Australians who will be left in a state of complete uncertainty as to whether or not, after the next election, this GST will be imposed, contrary to the commitments given by the government before(Time expired) Same-Sex Relationships living happily in communities all around Australia. Many of them do not wish to marry; some do. But until the recent legislation introduced by the Howard government, this question of gay marriage was not an issue in Australian politics. There was no community campaign seeking the right to marry on the part of gays and lesbians-some wish to; some do not. I support the amendments to the Marriage Act that the Howard government is putting forward, because they reflect the existing reality and the existing law, but I object strenuously to the homophobia being purveyed by the Howard government surrounding those amendments-the transparent attempt to inflame hatred of gays and lesbians in the community for political purposes. Ultimately we cannot vote on the motives behind a particular piece of legislation or indeed the rhetoric surrounding that legislation or who it is announced to but on the merit of the legislation. The vicious bullying strategy that we saw from the Howard government surrounding refugees in the last election is now sought to be replicated by attacks on gays and lesbians, and that is not something that I or the Labor Party are going to join in. We condemn it absolutely. Labor have already determined our policy on these issues some time ago-in fact, November last year-indicating that we do not support changing the definition of marriage away from heterosexual couples but we are committed to eliminating all forms of discrimination against gay and lesbian couples, whether it is in superannuation, taxation, immigration, property or family law. Inevitably there will be a need in our community for some means of formal recognition or formalisation of same-sex relationships to ensure that gay and lesbian couples can enjoy equivalent rights to those of heterosexual couples obtained through the marriage institution. As the shadow minister for community relationships, I am committed to pursuing some kind of formalisation available to gay and lesbian couples. Our society should support, acknowledge and recognise all loving, nurturing relationships as worthwhile. The formal mechanisms through which we do this may vary. We do not have to adapt an existing mechanism to suit other circumstances. We can create new mechanisms, and that is what we need to do to ensure that gay and lesbian couples can enjoy the same equivalent rights that married heterosexual couples enjoy in our society. I think the practical issues of discrimination are more important than the symbolism of the word ‘marriage’. We need to commit ourselves as a society to ensuring that those thousands of couples who do live happily in good, genuine, caring, loving relationships are able to enjoy the legal protections-and the responsibilities-that married couples also enjoy and that they have access to a framework of legal rights and responsibilities covering issues like property MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (12.44 P.m.)
theText: There are thousands of gay and lesbian couplesrights, custody of children, taxation, superannuation, social security and matters involving next of kin, such as organ donation and turning off life support. All of those issues can be covered in an equivalent legal relationship. I am proud that 10 years ago I was part of a government that legalised, finally, all homosexual activity between consenting adults in Australia. That in itself shows how far we have come as a society in such a very short time on these issues, but it also illustrates how far we have to go. It is a long, hard battle in Australia for decency, for equal rights and for fairness. I am committed to ensuring that we fight that battle to its ultimate conclusion. We must not allow the voices of hate, prejudice and religious fundamentalism to deter us. We must not let the desperate political manipulations of the Prime Minister get in the road of this important, vital pursuit of genuine human rights for all Australians. I have no doubt that in the past it has been Labor governments that have achieved the great steps forward in human rights in this country such as the abolition of the Tasmanian criminalising legislation 10 years ago, and I have no doubt that it will be Labor governments in the future that achieve these very important social gains. For all the posturing of the minor parties like the Greens and the Democrats, who demand everything overnight-safe in the knowledge that they do not have to deliver it, safe in the knowledge that they do not have to change community opinion, and safe in the knowledge that they do not have to win government to actually achieve those outcomes-it will be a Labor government in the future that delivers equal rights for gay and lesbian couples and gives them access to something like a civil union framework that ensures they have the ability to live, as couples, the same kinds of lives, with the same kinds of legal rights and responsibilities, as married heterosexual couples do in our society. East Timor Chisholm Electorate: Caroline Chisholm Awards Ms BURKE (Chisholm) (12.49 p.m.)-I rise today to express my gratitude and thanks to the Rotary Club of Huntingdale, which last Friday night hosted a dinner in honour of Kirsty Sword Gusmao, who spoke at the dinner. She spoke passionately about her adopted country and about her frustration at the current government’s futile attempts to refuse to negotiate with that country. I was very pleased to read in the paper about possible negotiations and to see in the gallery yesterday Jose Ramos Horta. Hopefully, those negotiations have recommenced, because for the current government to refuse to negotiate with East Timor is absolutely barbaric. East Timor is the newest nation on the earth and one of the poorest. To not give it justice in respect of its own resources is just criminal. East Timor is a country crying out with need. We are currently providing it aid; I do not see why we should not do a fair deal that gives it the resources so that it can provide for its own people. Kirsty went through some statistics. Unfortunately, I do not have them with me today but they were quite frightening. Particularly frightening were the rates of infant mortality and childhood diseases. It was stark to hear about a country that has been deserted by the international community. She talked about the Portuguese stance during their time in East Timor and how fundamentally they had not done anything on the ground. The Indonesians did even less, because they destroyed the country and took things away, well before the fatal invasion and the lead-up to the vote for independence. Kirsty spoke about her passion for and delight with MAIN COMMITTEE the Timorese people, a proud people who, in some respects because of their isolation, have been able to continue, maintain and foster their own culture. It was a delight to hear Kirsty, and it was a wonderful function for the Rotary Club of Huntingdale to organise. Rotarians throughout Australia but particularly in Victoria have been extremely generous in their support of Timor. Shipment upon shipment of goods has been sent across. Kirsty stressed that it is really good if you ask the Timorese what they are in need of before you ship something, because some things have arrived that are unusable. There is a lack of constant electricity; there is a lack of a constant power supply. One recent Rotary shipment was of old-style typewriters that we might think obsolete, but in a country that does not have a sufficient power supply it was an absolute godsend. We might not like paper and carbon, but over there they are keeping the system going. We would not want old-style, treadmill sewing machines, but in a country without a constant electricity supply they are an absolute bonus. We need to show justice to our neighbour, a country that fought with us and gave us aid during World War II, a country we have a proud history with. It is a disgrace that we have not been able to resolve the Sunrise gas contract to ensure that the project is up and running and that much needed royalties flow to East Timor, a country that is in great need. It is also very unfair for our government to say, ‘We’re only going to negotiate twice every year,’ as opposed to getting down to brass tacks and saying, ‘This is a new nation.’ There have been movements in maritime law. It is time to sit down and do justice for this nation. The Rotary Club of Huntingdale presented Kirsty with a cheque for $7,000, and more was raised on the night. It was an absolute privilege and joy to be there and to meet such an amazing woman, who had such wonderful, glowing things to say about her adopted country. I wish her well with her third pregnancy. I am not sure how she manages it. I do not know how we manage it in this place sometimes with our children, but this woman has two small children and another on the way and is running around the world trying to get justice for her adopted people. She is running the Alola Foundation for Timorese women, and it is doing phenomenally great work. We need to encourage support and to do more for this country. I would also like to state that this coming SaturdayI will be hosting the Caroline Chisholm awards, which I am pleased to be hosting for the fifth year in a row. I am hopeful that I will be home to attend the awards; my big message to the Senate is: let me go home to attend the awards. I am looking forward to over 500 people coming along and witnessing me saying thank you, on behalf of my community in Chisholm, to 30 volunteers and 50 runners-up who have given so much back to my community. Interfaith Dialogue Whiley, Mr Bill Norford, Mr Reg verse population in terms of ethnic background, language and religion. It is essential, therefore, that we take positive measures to build bridges, understanding and dialogue between Australians of diverse backgrounds and beliefs. We certainly do not want to allow the fundamentalists and purveyors of hatred to threaten our community harmony and to vilify and harMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Laurie Ferguson (Reid) (12.54 P.m.)
theText: Australia is a land of an increasingly diass fellow Australians. I think the recent events in Perth are at the extreme edge of that problem. Over the past few years I have been pleased to support many positive steps on the part of interfaith dialogue in Sydney. One of those is Affinity, which is essentially a Turkish organisation that has conducted a number of events including interfaith discussions, seminars and briefings et cetera and, most recently, the 3rd International Interfaith Conference at the University of Western Sydney at Rydalmere on 30 May. In relation to that visit, I was pleased to meet in my office Professor Ibrahim Ozdemir, a leading authority and worker in interfaith knowledge and work, on 28 May. Also, there are the Australian Partnership of Ethnic and Religious Organisations or for the Study of Jewish Civilisation. They held the Third International Inter-Religion Abraham Conference in Melbourne on 22 May. I also had the pleasure of attending an event in Adelaide in relation to this. The title gives you the gist of it-it is about Jews, Muslims and Christians working together around the commonality of Abraham’s contribution to their religions. Whilst national and international efforts are important, it is crucial that there is grassroots activity around these matters. I want to recognise the work of the Catholic Bishop of the Parramatta Diocese, Kevin Manning. Of course, we are aware that he also did a lot of work in regard to aircraft issues in our region. He and Keysar Trad from the Islamic community have been at the forefront of a number of local events. Crucial in this is that they are actually in the western suburbs, not suburbs that have a high Anglo-Saxon content. It is no good talking about these issues in Balmain, Glebe, Granville and Auburn. These events have been featured at Greystanes. I attended one at which there were about 500 people present. There was a very good and open exchange and an honest throwing of ideas around the room. More recently, on 30 July at Castle Hill, the theme was that Christians and Muslims have more in common than most people think. Annangrove has been subject to attacks on the site of a proposed Islamic prayer centre, so it is taking the issue out to where the forefront of the problems are. I congratulate all of those organisations. I want to join the member for Cunningham in recognising the contribution of Bill Whiley, who died very recently. Bill was a former Communist Party alderman in the Broken Hill City Council. He then played a major role in the miners federation on the South Coast and in many local campaigns. He must have been into his eighties when he expired. Recently he had been involved in the Sandon Point issue-that is a very controversial development issue down there. Every Christmas when I went down there I would go to the pub along the coast-I have forgotten the name of itBetween bets we would have discussions about politics. He was a very militant and active person on the South Coast who gave a lot to the Labor movement and the broader progressive politics of this country. He was a person who did not actually believe in any particular political party but strove to improve the condition of his fellow humans. His most recent activity of later years was to do with retired members of unions-superannuants and pensioners. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Price
theText: Did you go to both of them?
title: Apero Convened By The Federation Of Ethnic Communities Councils Of Australia Or Fecca The Australian Intercultural Society The Catholic Interfaith Committee And The Centre

speaker: Mr Laurie Ferguson
theText: Yes, I went to both of them fairly regularly on my holidays.I also want to recognise at this stage the recent death of former councillor Reg Norford of the Parramatta City Council. He was in there in the fifties and sixties during a period when Parramatta was probably at the forefront of activities with regard to libraries, baby health centres and those types of things. Norford Park in South Granville is named after him. He had a long tradition of political activity in our area and I want to recognise him. Both of those people made major contributions. I really appreciate the comments made by the member for Cunningham. We both knew Bill Whiley very well and we recognise his activities in the broader Wollongong region and in the broader Labor movement. Defence: Royal Australian Air Force reseal program. It has been an issue that has been ongoing for a long time. In fact, it started back in the 1970s and ran right through to the 1990s. It is something that is of grave concern to me and many of my constituents as RAAF base Amberley is a significant part of my electorate. The reason it has come back up for discussion is twofold. One reason is that there is a new report, Study of health outcomes in aircraft maintenance personnel: Phase II Mortality and cancer incidence study, the second report, April 2004. The other is the growing incidence of cancer related death or the suffering of the people who worked on those programs during the seventies right through to the 1990s. The first board of inquiry originally commissioned was the largest board of inquiry of its type to ever take place in Australia. This goes to show the level of complexity and the problems associated with the deseal-reseal program. I want to put on the record a couple of things which I think are really important. This report found quite conclusively a number of things, particularly with regard to the incidence of cancer. The study found a higher rate of the incidence of cancer in the deseal-reseal group with an increase of around 40 to 50 per cent relative to both the Amberley and Richmond comparison groups. The report found conclusively that there was a raised incidence. What disturbs me is that for a lot of years the government has known about this but has not acted. That to me is distressing. It is distressing to many of my constituents who live in my area and are suffering because of the work they undertook as part of their official duties with the Air Force. There have been a lot of changes since those days. When the report was originally tabled in 2001, Air Marshal Houston made a number of comments, and I want to put one on the record. He said, ‘While we cannot change the past, we can ensure that all current and future working environments are safe for our people.’ While I do not want to attribute anything in particular in terms of an admission from what he said, it is a clear indication that the practices in the past were bad; they were unsafe. I think there was a macho culture in the Air Force and right across our military. It was a culture which basically said that you did not have to wear protective clothing, eye protection or gloves when working with chemicals; in fact, it was frowned upon. There was a real culture that to be a man and work in these environments you did not need to be protected and that you would be okay. We now know that that is not the case; that these people did have high exposure to very poisonous and carcinogenic materials. They are now paying the penalty. Their families are suffering and they are suffering. They have high incidence rates of cancer and, as this very significant report of many hundreds of pages indicates, these people are suffering greatly. WhatI would like to see the government do, now it has the weight of evidence from this report that it needs, is to take the steps necessary to properly compensate and recognise the MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Apero Convened By The Federation Of Ethnic Communities Councils Of Australia Or Fecca The Australian Intercultural Society The Catholic Interfaith Committee And The Centre

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (12.59 P.m.)
theText: I want to raise the issue of the RAAF F111 desealsuffering of these people who were involved in the deseal-reseal programs from the seventies to the nineties. I think that there is a responsibility attached to government. While government is more than prepared to cloak itself in the flag of the military in times of war and in times of trouble and is more than prepared to take all the public benefits of its military, I think at the same time it has to take responsibility publicly for things that took place-no matter how long ago and no matter what the cost, because this does involve some matter of cost. The people and the families, many of whom I have spoken to personally, cannot understand why it has taken the government so long to do something about this. This commission of inquiry report, this phase II report, gives very hard evidence to what these people anecdotally have been telling us for a long time. I think it is enough evidence for the government now to take the responsible action of looking at proper compensation for the people affected. If we are going to be serious about this issue, just like in the James Hardie case where a company is responsible for its work force, so too must the military, the RAAF and the government accept responsibility. I think it is time that the government seriously looked at the findings of this report and properly compensated families for their suffering. (Time expired) Education: Teachers lar, the debate going on about the state school-private school divide. I have an immense respect for teachers. I think teachers are the custodians of the minds of our children. They do not just teach literacy and numeracy; they teach other subjects, like geography, history, sociology and many others, depending on what sort of school you go to. I therefore find it extraordinary that the organisation that represents them-at the national level the AEU and at the state level in Queensland the QTU-can indulge in such a dishonest campaign in respect of this matter of state and private funding. Their arguments are totally and utterly selective. They deny totally the states’ involvement in education. They concentrate totally on the federal part of the cake, which, as we all know, is the minor part of it. One of their great techniques is to pick out the eight or 10 schools of Sydney and Melbourne-schools like Wesley, Scotch, Trinity and King’s-and try to make the public believe that these are representative of all schools in Australia. They then quote the $2.6 million, the $3.2 million, the $3.5 million et cetera. Never anywhere in that debate is the per capita figure given-never! AndI just happen to have some of those figures-for example: Wesley, $2,380; King’s, $2,600; and Scots, $2,330. I do not say that as an apologist for those schools; I am not. I believe in choice. My kids attended both systems. In the private system one of my children attended a Catholic school. One of my children who had trouble with study went to a boarding school. Another one went to a state school. SoI am quite conversant with all three types of education, and I am not an apologist for any one of them. WhatI do want to see is fairness and equity in this system. Against those figures of around $2,000 to $3,000, you find that run-of-the-mill Catholic and Anglican Christian schools get between $4,500 and $5,500-at least, that is the Queensland experience. But the state schools get $11,700 in New South Wales, $10,590 in Victoria and $10,800 in Queensland. Parents, no matter where their kids are sent to school, have all contributed to the taxation system. No-one is suggesting for a minute that the children who go to well-endowed schools MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Apero Convened By The Federation Of Ethnic Communities Councils Of Australia Or Fecca The Australian Intercultural Society The Catholic Interfaith Committee And The Centre

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (1.04 P.m.)
theText: I wish to talk about schoolteachers and, in particushould get the same money as children who go to state schools. I have never argued that case. But to argue that they are not entitled to anything is distinctly un-Australian and dishonest. The QTU go around Queensland whipping up this campaign-they are going to launch it in my electorate, and I will be delighted to debate this issue with them-never telling the full story, selectively whipping up the idea of envy and division in the community and taking us back almost to the edge of that sectarian divide of 30 or 40 years ago, which was appalling. These are the custodians of the minds of our children. And the union are sending home in the lunch boxes of children selective material so it will get to parents. Is that an appropriate use of school facilities, making the kids take things home in their lunch box? I have been into a couple of school common rooms and seen noticeboards packed from end to end with ALP and Queensland Teachers Union literature-not a space for anything else. Is that the appropriate use of the state schools, which should be neutral grounds for people of all political persuasions? No, it is not appropriate. If the state schools are short, it is because the Queensland government in the 2003 budget could only afford a 2.4 per cent increase-it could not match the Commonwealth’s 5.4 per cent-and this year, after a record budget surplus, could only afford a 3.9 per cent increase against the Commonwealth’s 4.5 per cent. That robbed Queensland schools in 2003 of $116 million. Another interesting statistic, on which I will finish, is that the Catholic school system works on a bureaucracy and an administration figure of five per cent. Do you know what that figure is in the New South Wales state school system? It is 25 per cent. Let us direct that 20 per cent to the schoolchildren of the state schools of New South Wales. (Time expired) Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and its impact on my constituents in the electorate of Lowe, in the inner west of Sydney. As you know, I have spoken on innumerable occasions in the life of this parliament and the preceding parliament, and I have also asked an innumerable number of questions. I want to take the parliament through the history of this, because prior to the election of the Howard government in 1996 the coalition aviation policy, entitled ‘Soaring into tomorrow’, made it quite plain that Sydney airport would not be sold until the aircraft noise problems had been resolved. Also during that campaign of 1996, the Liberal candidate made it quite plain that under the Howard government there would be no new flight paths over the electorate of Lowe. That was challenged by the Labor Party in that campaign and it was made quite clear that this could not be achieved under the coalition’s policy. That came to be true. But, worse, since the government got in and promised that under the long-term operating plan those people living north of the airport would only receive 17 per cent of air traffic movements, we have tragically found that air traffic movements have, in the main, been 60 per cent to 80 per cent more and at the moment are running at almost double those promised under the long-term operating plan. Last year, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sydney airport was sold, with no resolution to the problems of aircraft noise. Worse, the master plan for Sydney airport over the next 20 years forecasts a massive expansion of air traffic in and out of Sydney because, as we all know, Sydney is the gateway to Australia. That is going to have horrendous consequences for people living in the inner west and particularly for people in my electorate of Lowe. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Apero Convened By The Federation Of Ethnic Communities Councils Of Australia Or Fecca The Australian Intercultural Society The Catholic Interfaith Committee And The Centre

speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (1.09 P.m.)
theText: I would like to again raise the issue of aircraft noiseI want to make the point that, under the government’s aviation policy, Badgerys Creek is still their preferred option. You might also remember that last year the opposition took the position that we could never have two major international airports within the Sydney basin, within about 40 kilometres of one another. We have decided that, subject to an EIS-and I note the member for members for Lindsay and Chifley are here, and they understand this very well-there should be a second airport outside the Sydney basin, in the Wilton region. The opposition, in the run-up to the next election, offers the full implementation of the long-term operating plan, which will give relief to my constituents in Lowe. Moreover, we will immediately take it upon ourselves to start an EIS so that we can put in train a process that will one day see a second airport built in the Wilton area, to take the pressure off Sydney airport. I want to also say something about the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional ServicesA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesMain Committee adjourned at 1.13 p.m. MAIN COMMITTEE The following answers to questions were circulated: Calwell Electorate: Veterans (Question No. 3214) Ms Vamvakinou asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 2004: (1) For the year (a) 2001-2002, and (b) 2002-2003, how many (i) veterans’ pension recipients, and (ii) veterans’ spouses resided in (A) the electoral division of Calwell and, the postcode area (B) 3036,(C) 3037, (D) 3038, (E) 3043, (F) 3046 (G) 3047, (H) 3048, (I) 3049, (J) 3059, (K) 3060, (L) 3061,(M) 3064, (N) 3427, and (O) 3428. (3) The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) provides reliable and affordable access to a wide range of necessary medicines for the community. The total number of RPBS prescriptions filled for Department of Veterans’ Affairs treatment cardholders are as follows: (a) 2002-2003 (b) 2003-2004* (i) Victoria 3,306,258 1,724,264 (ii) Electoral Division of Calwell 67,732 35,007 (iii) Postcode 3036 4,683 2,522 (iv) Postcode 3037 1029 690 (v) Postcode 3038 3,478 2,122 (vi) Postcode 3043 5,394 2,622 (vii) Postcode 3046 28,741 14,439 (viii) Postcode 3047 7,399 3,661 (ix) Postcode 3048 2,322 1,218 (x) Postcode 3049 1,915 992 (xi) Postcode 3059 476 268 (xii) Postcode 3060 7,025 3,614 (xiii) Postcode 3061 696 277 (a) 2002-2003 (b) 2003-2004* (xiv) Postcode 3064 3,615 1,850 (xv) Postcode 3427 825 634 (xvi) Postcode 3428 134 98 * Number of RPBS Prescriptions Filled from 1 July 2003 31 December 2003 Ashwah, Mr Fouad El (Question No. 3471) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004: (1) Is the Minister aware of the article titled ‘The man who acts as Islam’s Ruddock’ on the front page of the Weekend Australian on 26 July 2003 which: refers to a person registered on the electoral roll as Mr Fouad El Ashwah at an address in Regents Park in the electorate of Reid; features a photograph of Mr El Ashwah in the company of the Attorney General, Mr Ruddock, and other Liberal party figures; refers to allegations that a message in Arabic from Mr El Ashwah on office stationery of the then Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Mr Ruddock, was being distributed in Western Sydney; quotes the Lebanese Muslim Association as confirming that Mr El Ashwah had, on more than one occasion, personally arranged for Mr Ruddock to visit the Lakemba mosque; states that Mr El Ashwah is president of the Auburn branch of the Liberal Party and that he had been seated next to Mr Ruddock at a Liberal Party fundraiser in Auburn; includes a claim that officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs had warned Mr Ruddock about Mr El Ashwah’s activities on migration matters; and concludes with a statement from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to the effect that allegations concerning Mr El Ashwah were under investigation. (2) Can the Minister explain the basis on which the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs provided written advice to the Senate Committee on Ministerial Discretion in Migration Matters on 14 January 2004 that “DIMIA has not been able to identify the person referred to as Fouad El Ashwah”. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question. (1) Yes. (2) The Department’s written advice to the Committee on this matter was in response to a question passed orally from the Committee to the Department seeking information on the outcome of a request for Ministerial intervention for Fouad El Ashwah. A search of departmental reporting systems at the time was unable to identify a person by that name who was, or had been, the subject of a Ministerial intervention request. The Department’s response to the Committee was made on that basis. Defence: Southern Ocean Surveillance (Question No. 3533) 11 May 2004: (1) On how many days did marine patrols operate in the Southern Ocean during (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004.

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Defence, Upon Notice, On
theText: (2) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, (i) which vessel or vessels conducted patrols in the Southern Ocean, and (ii) how many days did each vessel conduct patrols. (3) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, how many personnel undertook Southern Ocean patrol duties and which government agency employed them. (4) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, what was the total cost to each agency of operating Southern Ocean patrols, and of this, what sum was attributable to (i) leasing or chartering cost, (ii) operating and maintenance costs, (iii) personnel costs, and (iv) other costs. (5) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, which vessels in the Southern Ocean were (i) intercepted, (ii) subject to administrative seizure, and (iii) apprehended. (6) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, in respect to each vessel intercepted in the Southern Ocean, (i) where was it registered, and (ii) what was the nature of the illegal activity it was engaged in. Fran Bailey-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The unclassified information that I can provide is as follows. The Australian Defence Force (ADF) does not conduct ship based patrols as such in the Southern Oceans. During the relevant period the ADF did however operate a number of operation deployments. Resources referred to in this answer relate to those deployments and are limited to ADF resources except where otherwise stated. (1) (a) 44 days. (b) nil. (c) 46 days. (2) (a), (i) and (ii) HMAS Canberra 22 days, HMAS Westralia 22 days. (b), (i) and (ii) Not applicable. (c), (i) and (ii) HMAS Warrumunga 18 days, HMAS Success 28 days. (3) (a) 265 ADF personnel and three Australian Fisheries Management Authority officers. (b) One ADF member participated in a Customs surveillance patrol. (c) 363 ADF personnel, two Australian Fisheries Management Authority officers and one Customs officer engaged in operational deployments to the Southern Ocean region in ADF units, and six ADF personnel participated in two Customs surveillance patrols. (4) (a) The net additional cost (1) of the ADF deployment was $20,000. (b) Nil. (c) The net additional cost (1) of the ADF deployment was $405,000. Note (1): The net additional cost reflects the true cost to the taxpayer of undertaking an operation and recognises that the ADF is already funded by the Government to raise, train and maintain personnel and equipment in preparation for operational contingencies. The net additional cost of an operation includes such things as any special equipment purchases required, airlift costs, additional personnel costs such as rations and allowances, extra fuel used by assets employed and remediation costs on completion of the operation. (5) (a) (i) Lena and Volga. (ii) Nil. (iii) Lena and Volga. (b) (i), (ii) and (iii) Nil. (c) (i) Maya V. (ii) Nil. (iii) Maya V. (6) (a) (i) Both the Lena and the Volga were registered in Russia. (ii) Conducting fishing operations in contravention of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. (b) Not applicable. (c) (i) The MayaV was registered in Uruguay. (ii) Conducting fishing operations in contravention of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. Treasury: Terrorism and Dealings with Assets (Question No. 3565) (1) What assistance do agencies in his portfolio provide in upholding the Charter of the United Nations (Terrorism and Dealings with Assets) Regulations 2002 and Australia’s obligations to freeze terrorist assets under United Nations Security Council Resolution 1373. (2) In respect of each agency involved in providing this assistance, (a) how many staff are involved in this work, (b) in which group, division, branch or other work unit are they located, (c) what is the nature of the assistance they provide, (d) what are their classifications, (e) what are their other duties, and (f) what was the cost in (i) 2002-2003, and (ii) 2003-2004 of employing these staff. (1) The relevant agency in the portfolio is the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) and assistance provided by it is detailed in 2(c) below. (2) (a) Two. (b) Serious Non-Compliance Business Line. (c) The ATO can freeze any tax refund that would otherwise be due to a person or entity listed under these regulations. In March/April 2002 the ATO undertook an exercise using ATO computer matching systems in an attempt to identify any persons or entities on the December 2001 and March 2002 lists. No person or entity was positively identified as a result of this exercise. Since the initial exercise was undertaken as described above, later lists have been checked against ATO databases. The position is unchanged – still no person or entity has been identified. In the event that a person or identity was positively identified administrative steps would be taken to ensure that in the event of a refund becoming due it would be frozen. (d) 1 x Executive Level1 1 x Australian Public Service Officer Level5 (e) The two officers are involved in dealing with other matters that are within the province of the business line. (f) The function of checking the lists is a minor part of the overall duties performed by the two officers and hence no separate costings can be provided.

title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:ing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Recommendations numbered 6,7, 8,10,13,14,15, and 24 through to 29. (2) The following officers of my department have been involved in preparing the Government’s response to the report announced on 29 July 2004: Officer level Number of officers Deputy Secretary 1 SES Band2 1 SES Band1 2 Executive Level2 4 Executive Level1 3 FACS 3 1 (3) (a) As soon as the Committee’s Report was tabled. (b) On 29 July the Prime Minister announced a package of proposed reforms to the family law system in response to the recommendations made in the Every Picture Tells a Story report. The Government will be releasing a discussion paper on the implementation of the proposed reforms and seeking input from the community on how they should be taken forward. A Child Support Taskforce will be established to review the child support scheme, including the recommendations of the child custody report, and to report back by March 2005. (4) It is not appropriate to provide details concerning Cabinet business. (5) No specific allocation was made in the 2004-05 Budget. Citizenship Ceremonies (Question No. 3632 amended answer) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 15 June 2004: (1) To which Members and Senators has he issued a standing delegation to preside at Australian citizenship ceremonies. (2) Does a standing delegation entitle a Member or Senator to preside, without further approval, at (a) a ceremony conducted under the auspices of a Local Council, (b) a ceremony conducted under the auspices of a community group or service club, (c) a public ceremony organised by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, and (d) a private ceremony. (3) Does anything prevent a Member or Senator from conducting a ceremony at (a) their electorate office, (b) a private residence or farm, or (c) a place of business. (4) Since the release of the revised Australian Citizenship Ceremonies Code in August 2003, how many community organisations and service clubs have received approval to conduct a citizenship ceremony. (5) Which community organisations and service clubs have received approval to conduct a citizenship ceremony and, in respect of each ceremony, (a) when was it conducted, (b) in which electoral division was it conducted, (c) how many applicants were conferred citizenship, and (d) which federal and state Members of parliament were in attendance. (6) Did officers of the department attend all the ceremonies referred to in part (5); if not, for which ceremonies were they not in attendance. In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard page 31953 of 3 August 2004:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the follow
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) As at 2 July 2004, the following Members of the House of Representatives had been given a standing delegation to preside at Australian citizenship ceremonies: Mr Phillip Barresi MP, Member for Deakin; Mr Bob Baldwin MP, Member for Paterson; Mr Joel Fitzgibbon MP, Member for Hunter; Mr Luke Hartsuyker MP, Member for Cowper; Ms Kelly Hoare MP, Member for Charlton; Mr Michael Johnson MP, Member for Ryan; Mr Peter Lindsay MP, Member for Herbert; Mr Jim Lloyd MP, Member for Robertson; Mrs Margaret May MP, Member for McPherson; Ms Sophie Panopoulos MP, Member for Indi; Mr Chris Pearce MP, Member for Aston; The Hon Philip Ruddock MP, Member for Berowra; Mr Alby Schultz MP, Member for Hume; The Hon Peter Costello MP, Member for Higgins; The Hon Warren Entsch MP, Member for Leichhardt; Mrs Kay Hull MP, Member for Riverina; and Mr Barry Wakelin MP, Member for Grey. A standing delegation has not been given to any Senator. (2) (a) to (d) Yes. (3) (a) to (c) The delegation to confer citizenship does not prescribe a location. All Members provided with a standing delegation have signed an agreement to abide by the Australian Citizenship Ceremonies Code. The Code outlines the expectation that new citizens will generally be conferred with citizenship in public ceremonies conducted by local government or community groups. The Code also outlines the circumstances in which a private ceremony may be appropriate. (4) and (5)(a) Details of all citizenship ceremonies conducted by community organisations and service clubs are not held centrally and are not readily available. Collation of this information would require a manual examination of files in all Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) State and Territory offices. This would be an unreasonable diversion of departmental resources, which I am not prepared to authorise. (5) (b) My Department does not keep records of the electoral divisions in which citizenship ceremonies are held. (c) The number of conferees at each ceremony is not readily available without an unreasonable diversion of resources. However, as a result of recent changes to my Department’s citizenship data system, there will be a record of the number of conferees at each ceremony held on or after 1 July 2004. (d) My Department sends out invitations to public citizenship ceremonies in accordance with the Australian Citizenship Ceremonies Code. Records are not kept of who actually attends. (6) Records of departmental officers’ attendance at the ceremonies are not readily available without an unreasonable diversion of resources. Health and Ageing: Aged Care Places (Question No. 3661) Ms Hall asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 17 June 2004: What sum has been allocated in the budget for (a) existing operational beds, and (b) new beds yet to become operational. Ms Julie Bishop-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (a) and (b) Funding for aged care places is a special appropriation under the Aged Care Act 1997 and is therefore not part of the annual appropriation Budget Bills. Estimates of expense under the Act are based on expected levels of operational places. Under the Act, a subsidy is not payable until a place becomes operational. The estimate in the 2004-05 budget of $5.088 billion includes provision for existing operational beds ($4.8 billion) and for those expected to become operational in the course of the year ($287 million).
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the followHealth and Ageing: Aged Care Facilities (Question No. 3663) Ms Hall asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 17 June 2004: What was the effect of coalescence on money lost on aged care facilities. Ms Julie Bishop-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The Funding Equalisation and Adjustment Package (FEAP) replaced the coalescence policy from 200001. This followed confirmation by the independent Productivity Commission that there was no basis for differential subsidy rates across the States and Territories. In response to the Productivity Commission’s 1999 Report on Nursing Home Subsidies, the Australian Government provided $148 million over six years from 2000-01 to further ease the transition of aged care services to consistent national rates. Following the release of new rates of subsidy effective 1 July 2004, all States and Territories except Victoria and Tasmania now have the same subsidy rates. Victoria and Tasmania will continue to be paid above the national average until 1 July 2006. The transition to achieve consistent national rates is being achieved through incremental differential subsidy rate increases over the six year period. There will be no decrease in subsidy rates in any State or Territory during the transition to nationally consistent rates. Environment and Heritage: Planning and Environmental Laws (Question No. 3671) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 22 June 2004: Will he review the operation and interaction of Commonwealth and NSW planning and environmental laws so that Commonwealth land use, such as land affected by the Airports Act 1979 and ‘works’ and ‘activities’ as defined in the NSW Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 on other Commonwealth land, are developments made subject to the NSW Forward Planning Scheme, under the NSW Act; if not why not. swer to the honourable member’s question: Where appropriate, Australian Government activities are subject to NSW legislation or achieve equivalent requirements through Australian Government legislation. The Airports Act 1996 provides a comprehensive and uniform approach to land use, planning and environmental management issues in relation to leased airports. Part5 of the Airports Act, which relates to land use, planning and building controls, is expressed to apply to the exclusion of State or Territory laws in relation to land use planning or the regulation of building activities. A requirement to comply with State and Territory laws would produce unnecessary duplication. However, consistency with State or Territory laws is considered in relation to the development and management of leased Australian Government Airports. For example, under s.71(6) of the Airports Act, an Airport master plan must address the extent of consistency with planning schemes in force under a law of the State or Territory in which the airport is located, in relation to specified land-use or development objectives or proposals. Defence: Maldives National Security Service (Question No. 3675) Mr Rudd asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 June 2004:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following anWhat contact is there and has there been previously between the Maldives National Security Service and the Australian Defence Force. Fran Bailey-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The Australian Defence Force has had contact with the Maldives National Security Service. Since July 2002 contact with the Maldives has included: port visits by HMAS Canberra in July 2002 and HMAS Newcastle in July-August 2003; C-130 transits of Malé in 2002, when Diego Garcia was not available; and a representative from the Maldives attended the Regional Military Health Interoperability Forum and the Asia-Pacific Military Medical Conference in Brisbane in May 2004. Defence: F111 Aircraft (Question No. 3681) Mr Price asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 2004: Has the Defence Science and Technology Organisation been tasked to undertake projects in relation the F111; if so, in respect of each project, (a) what is it, (b) how many personnel have been assigned to it, (c) what is its cost, (d) when was it commenced, (e) which are ongoing, and (f) when is it programmed to finish. Fran Bailey-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Yes. (a) The Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) conducts an integrated program of work in support of the F-111. This was conducted from the acquisition phase of the aircraft and throughout its in-service phase to the present. In this context, DSTO has provided science and technology advice concerning aircraft structural integrity, engines and fuels, paints and sealants, corrosion, accident investigation, wiring, electronic warfare, weapons, and analysis of strike operations. (b) The actual number of DSTO personnel assigned to projects in relation to the F-111 can not be readily quantified as DSTO’s involvement with the F-111 commenced in 1969. (c) Actual DSTO costs to perform F-111 tasks have been principally salary costs. The Royal Australian Air Force as the sponsor of F-111 tasks provides funds to DSTO to conduct specific tasks. (d) DSTO has provided support to the F-111 since 1969. (e) DSTO continues to support the ADF through an integrated program of work. This includes tasks performed on, inter alia, aircraft structural integrity, engines and fuels, electronic warfare, and corrosion. (f) DSTO will continue to provide ongoing support to the F-111 across a range of areas until the aircraft is retired. Aviation: Flight Guard (Question No. 3700) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 August 2004: (1) Is he aware of reports that Israel is planning to install ‘Flight Guard’ on civilian aircraft to protect against shoulder-fired surface to air missiles. (2) Is he aware that ‘Flight Guard’ was recently tested and that the radar automatically spotted the Strella SA7 missile, launched flares, and that the missiles chased after the flares. (3) Has he or his Department evaluated this system for possible use in Australia; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not. (4) Is he able to say whether any commercial airlines in Australia have expressed interest in the system or evaluated it. (5) Is the Government evaluating any other anti-missile systems for civilian aircraft and has it provided advice to Qantas on the installation of anti-missile systems. (6) Is the Defence Science and Technology Organisation involved in research on anti-missile systems for Australian military or commercial aircraft. (1) Yes. (2) I am aware that Israel has been testing the ‘Flight Guard’ missile countermeasures system, for planned use on certain of its civil aircraft fleet. (3) No. Assessment of such equipment is a commercial decision for the airlines based on their respective risk assessments. (4) No. (5) No. (6) This question should be directed to my colleague, the Minister for Defence. Iraq (Question No. 3709) Mr Andren asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 3 August 2004: What has been the impact, in Australian dollars, of the war in Iraq on Australia’s trade with Iraq. Australia’s exports to Iraq were valued at $315 million for the financial year 2003/04, slightly above the 10 year average of $308 million, but down from $360 million in 2002/03. In addition, Australian companies have secured a number of US-funded contracts for Iraq’s reconstruction estimated to be worth over $300 million. Iraq’s imports to Australia fell from $37 million in 2002/03 to $19 million in 2003/04.
